title: Abode of Kaviguru: Jorasanko
review_text: Tagore’s birthplace is Kolkata and not Shantiniketan! Located in Jorasanko, North Kolkata, his ancestral home is better known as ‘Jorasanko Thakurbari’ (scripted on the entry gate as well). Built by the poet’s grandfather, Prince Dwarikanath Tagore in the 18th century, the entrance plaque reads ‘Rabindranath was born and breathed his last here’. Though the building has been recognized as Rabindra Bharati University, a part of this 217 years old erection is a museum (Rabindra Bharati Museum) to Tagore’s family culture and customs. The poet spent most of his childhood days and his final days in this house. Tagore family was always highbrow and ahead of their time. The museum held galleries dedicated to Tagore family with their photographs. It showcases emerging of Tagore into a world famous poet and finally a Nobel laureate. Along with the poet’s works and paintings the galleries display works of other distinguished family members like Maharshi Devendranath Tagore (poet’s father) and Abanindranath Tagore (poet’s nephew). Every year Rabinndra Bahrati museum celebrates Bengali New Year, poet’s birthday and other such cultural programs. More

title: An Illustrous House of Culture!
review_text: Tagore is Bengal's greatest 20th century poet, the first Asian to win the Nobel prize and this was the house where he was born in 1861 and where he died in 1941. Jorasanko Thakur Bari is inseparable from the cultural heritage of all Bengalis. It is also one of the grand mansions of Old Calcutta, built in the 18th century. I was back after 10 years and glad to see that there are now exhibits devoted to Tagore's relationship with the US as well as China and Japan. And a whole new section on his final illness, surgery and death. Although the house is well maintained, the signage needs improvement. They will send you to the third floor first and it takes a while to figure out that this was where Tagore's grandfather lived. There are often few clues as to how other rooms were used and who were the residents. Instead, there is an overabundance of literary texts and artifacts. For Westerners, it can be a little perplexing, especially if you're not familiar with the history of the house, the family and Tagore's work. Some preliminary research is recommended. The best way to get here is to take the metro to Girish Park station. It's an easy walk from there. More

Its main attraction is of course that the Noble Laureate Rabindranath Tagore was born here, lived here and died here. Some of his most critical works were written here. 
The name Jorasanko is derived from the fact that there was a pair (jora) of small bridges (sanko) that led to the house. The house was built by Nilmoni Tagoe and was constantly modified and added to by the later occupants. The house that we see today is the handiwork of Prince Dwarkanath Tagore the grandfather of Rabindranath. Dwarkanath had also built a Baithak khana or reception section where he entertained his English friends and acquaintances. Later this was the residence of two great painters of the Tagore family – Gaganendranath and Abanindranath who established the Bengal school of painting. Unfortunately for reasons not known Rabindranath’s son Rathindranath demolished the house. 
The Joransko was home not only to Rabindranath but also to his highly gifted brothers and sisters. His eldest brother Dwijendranath was a scholar, poet and music composer. His songs are still sung specially at Brahmo festivals. Satyendranth was the first Indian to join the Indian Civil Service. 
Jyoirindranath (always referred to as Jyoti da by Rabindranath) was a poet, dramatist and composer of many songs and a music composer. He had great influence on Rabindranath in his formative years. Amongst his sisters Swarnakumari Devi was a gifted writer, song-composer and social worker. 
On entering the house there is a large courtyard where the Major Brahmo festival was held on the 11th day of Magh, corresponding to 25th January. Large number of people assembled here to listen to the sermons and songs of Rabindranath himself. The songs were sung by family members initially and in later years Rabindranath brought down the singers from his school in Santiniketan. 
On one side of the main building is the entrance to the upper floors that has now been converted into a museum. The entrance fee is Rs 10 for Indians and Rs 50 for foreigners. The rooms display photos and furniture. The visitor can see the room where Rabindranath died, the room where he was born and the room where his wife Mrinalini Devi died. There are also rooms related to the visits to different countries by Rabindranath as well as paintings of Gaganendranath and Abanindranath. 
Undoubtedly a great work of restoration has been done in the recent past. I recollect the great depredation that had taken place of the building through years of neglect. 
However some of the places are still out of bound. The rooms where Kadambari devi (the sister in law of Rabindranath lived and committed suicide) is not open to the public. Kadambari Devi ( whom Tagore always referred to as Nutan Bouthan) had a lasting influence on Rabindranath – both in his songs, poems and paintings. 
Unfortunately no photos are allowed inside the museum. Nor can photos be taken of the outside from the museum. 
The museum centres mainly on Rabindranath but not much is mentioned about the great family that resided here and was the leading light of the Bengal Renaissance in 19th century. 
One of the major attractions not known to many are the functions held on 11th of Magh the foundation day of the Brahmo Samaj in the Courtyard, thus continuing the tradition of the Tagore Family. More

title: A pilgrimage of another kind
review_text: As you get off the narrow and congested Chitpur Road and turn into the alley on which Thakurbari stands , the first thing to strike you is the sheer size of the edifice . There are several such ' palaces ' in North Calcutta but this one stands out not only for its imposing stature but because of its aura as the cultural mascot of Calcutta . As the ancestral home of Rabindranath , a poet , playwright, painter , thinker par excellence ( and above all a humanist respected the world over ) Thakurbari holds a special place in every Bengali's heart . It also has a large no of visitors from outside Bengal , and indeed from other parts of the world . The exhibits inside include selections from his vast literary oeuvre, as well as his exquisite paintings and some of the more significant phases of his life are showcased tastefully. The soothing music that plays in the background is from his own oeuvre. The visit would typically last about 2-3 hours and leave you fulfilled. The entrance fee is a pittance. More

title: Tagore house
review_text:
Jorasanko Thakur Bari in Jorasanko, is the ancestral home of the Tagore family. It is the house in which the poet and first non-European Nobel laureate, Rabindranath Tagore was born. It is also the place where he spent most of his childhood and died on 7 August 1941. 
The house has been restored to reflect the way the household looked when the Tagore family lived in it and currently serves as the Tagore museum for Kolkata. The museum offers details about the history of the Tagore family including its involvement with the Bengal Renaissance and the Brahmo Samaj. 
A visit to Jorasanko Thakur Bari is always an exhilarating experience.. Apart from the heritage routine, Rabindra Bharati University organizes regular cultural programmes on the poet’s birthday, Panchise Baisakh, when thousands flock to Jorasanko Thakur Bari and on other occasions, such as his death anniversary, Baishe Shravan. It also organises a festival of arts, Aban Mela. More

title: Jorasanko Thakurbari

title: Historic museum
review_text: Very clean, beautiful and historic place right in the middle of densely populated area of Kolkata, Jorasanko Thakurbari was the residence of the Tagore family. In my childhood, I had always read Tagore poems and excerpts from his life. It was a humbling experience visiting the house where he spent most of his days. There are lots of interesting artifacts preserved for public display. As you enter, to the left is Vichitra Bhawan. The hall was considered to be the heart of Bengal's cultural revolution. Noted scholars used to visit and discuss varied subjects in that hall, under the guidance of Abanindranath Togore. When I went there, I realized how culturally rich the Tagore family was in their time. Not only Rabindranath Togore, but paintings, beds, clothes, medals of other prominent members of the family has been preserved for public display. Painting of Rabindranath Tagore are at display in Vichitra Bhawan. You can learn a lot about his travels (there is a separate Japanese and Chinese section devoted to his travels in the two countries), prominent scholars of those time with whom he was close to, and of course his poems. It was an enriching experience for me and I would personally recommend everyone to take at least 1-2 hours to feel, explore and experience Thakurbari. Tucked away in the busy parts of North Kolkata narrow lanes and by-lanes, it is a place that is a must visit for anyone interested in Tagore and his life. It is the home of Tagore in his early childhood and it will give you the feel of his life and times. The display galleries are extremely interesting and well chronicled. History is presented in the form of writings, paintings, Gurudev's articles, photographs in the rooms that were once a part of Tagore's legendary family. 
There are some air-conditioned rooms too displaying Tagore's connection to various parts of the world like China and Japan. One can spend an entire day here going around the galleries. 
The fees is minimum but one is not allowed to carry any phones or bags inside. There are lockers to keep your belongings while you are visiting. 
The only shortcoming of this place is that some of the displays are described only in Bengali which is Tagore's mother-tongue without any English translation. So one might miss out on some parts if you are unable to read the script. 
A must visit in Kolkata if you are interested in Tagore and his creativity. More

title: Enchanting experience...
review_text:
We had visited the Jorasanko Thakurbari or (the home of the Thakurs of Jorasanko ) in Nov-Dec 2013. The ancestral home of Gurudev Rabindranath Tagore is a typical traditional bengali home with a rectangular courtyard in the center and verandahs on all the 4 sides. The Thakurbari has a good collection of photos and paintings- most prominently of Ravindranath Tagore and his uncle - the great painter Abarindranath Tagore along with framed excerpts of Tagore's poems all over the house. There are also charts explaining the family tree and describing the achievements of the family members. Its impossible to believe that a single family can have such a vast pool of talent. The Thakurbari was undoubtedly, the nerve center of Bengal's rich tradition of art and culture and its members have given our land progressive ideas, ideals and thought. The Thakurbari also has a few newly opened galleries apropos the cultural exchanges between Indian and China and India and Japan. The entire place is very well maintained and has a flavour of serenity and calmness to it -- just as one would expect Gurudev Tagore's home to have. Certainly worth a visit. 
Tips: 
1. This place is closed on Mondays and Thursdays. 
2. The nearest Metro station is Girish park Metro Station. More

title: Bengal's 'God' was born and died here
review_text:
Jorasanko is in the north of Kolkata and the 'Thakur Bari' is on Chitpur Road. The word Thakur comes from the surname of the Tagore family. Tagore is the English version of Thakur or respected land lord.' Bari' is Bengali for home. 

Rabindranath Tagore,the Nobel Laureate for literature, spent his childhood days here. It was also here that he breathed his last. Though for the major part of his life,Tagore lived in Shantiniketan, where he wrore Geetanjali for which he recieved the Nobel Prize 

Thakur Bari can be approached from Chittaranjan Avenue and Chitpur Road. If you wish to see the decadence of zamindari (rich land lords) era of Bengal, enter from Chitpur Road. The road is narrow and you can ride the tram car that labors its way through the congested road to Jorasanko Thakur Bari. 

The house is still maintained to an extent and you can see the room where Tagore was born, known as the 'antur ghar' and the large room where he breathed his last. Do read about Rabindranath Tagore's life before you step in, you will easily be able to co-relate the time when Chitpur Road thrived on literature, music, drama and intellectuals. More

title: Place where Nobel laureate Rabindra Thakur was born
review_text:
The Jorasanko Thakur Bari in Jorasanko, north of Kolkata, West Bengal, India is the ancestral home of the Tagore family. It is currently located on the Rabindra Bharati University campus at 6/4 Dwarakanath Tagore Lane, Jorasanko, Kolkata 700007. 
It was built in the 18th century by Prince Dwarkanath Tagore (Rabindranath Tagore's grandfather). It is the house in which the poet and first non-European Nobel laureate, Rabindranath Tagore was born. It is also the place where he spent most of his childhood and died on 7 August 1941.

title: Good only for its historical value
review_text: We went to Jorasanko Thakur Bari on the 150th birth anniversary of Tagore. It is a sad to see the house where Rabindranath Tagore was born and died in such a poor condition. The ground floor was in repairs with concrete and stones all over the place. The collection is poor compared to the extensive work of Rabindranath Tagore. It is worth visiting if you are a fan of Rabindranath Tagore.

title: Sense of history
review_text: This place has so much history associated with it! The Thakurs were one of the most influential families of Kolkata, Nobel laureate Rabindranath Tagore being the most famous member, but there were others equally talented like him, for example the great painters Gaganendranath and Abanindranath. The house is located on the oldest street of Kolkata: Chitpur road, now called Rabindra Sarani, a very congested road, but you have to be there to feel the real Kolkata. Lots of historical places are within walking distance from here and great sweet shops (famous Bengali mishti)!!!

title: Jorasanko Thakoor Bari – The Tagore Heritage in Kolkata
review_text:
If you are interested to learn about the life and family of the Nobel Prize winner poet of India Rabindranath Tagore, then you must visit Jorasanko Thakoor Bari in Kolkata. 

Many of the personal belongings of Rabindranath are displayed besides excellent paintings by his brother Abanindranath. 

We could not bring back any images as photography within the museum and art gallery is not permitted though we were able to pictures of the building from outside. 

History of Bengal is incomplete without Tagore and that is why the birthplace of Tagore is a heritage site in West Bengal. At present the house forms a part of the Vishwabharati University. 

Best time to visit is 25th day of Baisakh, the first month of Indian calendar and birthday of Rabindranath. More

title: Rabindranath Tagore's Home and Museum.
review_text: This is one place worth visiting to see and learn about the life of Rabindranath Tagore at his family home in Kolkata. There are many of his personal effects on display and three different galleries display paintings of the era by him and his illustrious brother Abanindranath Tagore besides some other painters too. Photography is not permitted inside the museum and art galleries but you can take pictures of the building from the outside.
